TextView.android:text: 1. Alphabet Overview: Below are the nine shorthand strokes you learned in Lesson 1. How quickly can you read them?
2 O, R, L In this paragraph you will study three extremely useful strokes o, r, l.
O The shorthand stroke for o is a small deep hook
R The shorthand stroke for r is a short forward curve.
L The shorthand stroke for 1 is a longer forward curve about three times as long as the stroke for r.
• Observe how these three strokes are derived from their longhand forms.

• Notice that in the terms in the third column, the letter o is oriented horizontally before n and m. This allows us to create smoother, more fluid outlines compared to what we would achieve if we wrote the o in an upright position in these and related words.
• Note that the sounds f-r, as in 'freed,' and f-l, as in 'floor,' can be produced in one continuous motion of the pen, without pausing between the f and the r or l.

3. H- Ing The letter 'h' is indicated by a dot placed above the following vowel. Typically, 'h' is found at the beginning of a word, though there are some exceptions. 'Ing,' which usually appears at the end of a word, is also denoted by a dot.
4 Long I The symbol used to represent the long i sound, like in the word 'my,' is a big broken circle..

5 Omission of Minor Vowels Numerous words in the English language have vowels that are only lightly pronounced or slurred. For instance, 'even' is actually pronounced as e-vn, and 'meter' is pronounced as met-r. (These subtle vowels are referred to as 'schwas' by the dictionary.) In shorthand, these vowels are often omitted when leaving them out does not affect the ease of writing or readability.
